title: Egypt speaker praises Hitler in bizarre attempt to back President's building plans
text:
Egypt's parliamentary speaker has received furious backlash after praising Hitler's infrastructure projects.

Ali Abdel Aal said: 'Hitler had his mistakes but what allowed him to expand eastward and westward was that he created a strong infrastructure.'

He made the comments while defending Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi's proposed development plans.

Ali Abdel Aal said: 'Hitler had his mistakes but what allowed him to expand eastward and westward was that he created a strong infrastructure'

He has since said that he only meant to praise German development and civilisation and that accusations of him praising the Nazi dictator are 'illogical'.

Abdel Aal called on the audience to stand for a minute of silence to show support for Sisi's plans to build a 'modern Egyptian state'.

Adolf Hitler ruled Nazi Germany between 1933 and 1945 and saw to the murder of 11million people - six million of whom were killed for being Jewish.

He made the comments while defending Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi's (pictured) proposed development plans

Abdel Aal's comments come after a spate of anti-Sisi demonstrations where protesters accused the president of corruption.

The protests began on September 20 and were triggered by an Egyptian whistleblower who filmed himself accusing Sisi and other officials of corruption and misappropriation of public funds.

Mohamed Ali has gained fame since the beginning of September when he started uploading daily videos exposing details of palaces built for Sisi using state funds.

Abdel Aal's comments come after a spate of anti-Sisi demonstrations where protesters accused the president of corruption

The protests were triggered by videos filmed by Egyptian whistleblower Mohamed Ali (pictured) which accused the president of corruption and misappropriation of state funds

Sisi responded by saying he did build palaces and 'will build more and more' because they are built 'for Egypt', according to Middle East Eye.

The country has declared a period of austerity in recent years and 30 per cent of its population are living in poverty.

The fifth round of the Egyptian Parliament started on Tuesday and it is the last round before the next election in 2020.

Egyptian protesters gather in downtown Cairo shouting anti-government slogans during a demonstration
